user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__connections:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__connections (const char *param_name, const char *param_tail,
                            const char *next_param)
{
  unsigned int param_value;
  enum PerfRepl_param_result value_res;

  value_res = get_param_value (param_name, param_tail, next_param,
                               &param_value);
  if (PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR == value_res)
    return value_res;

  if (0 == param_value)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "'0' is not valid value for parameter '%s'.\n",
             param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.connections = param_value;
  return value_res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No pointer targets in the provided code fragment violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13: • The function parameters param_name, param_tail and next_param are declared as const char *, so pointer targets are already const-qualified. • The only non-const pointer usage is &param_value passed to get_param_value; that is an output parameter and therefore must be a non-const unsigned int * (const would prevent writing the result), so it is appropriate not to be const. • The use of param_name in fprintf is passing a const char * to a function that accepts const char * for format arguments, so no violation. • The stderr FILE* is non-const by design and not subject to this rule. • The assignment tool_params.connections = param_value involves no pointer target in this fragment; the type of connections is not shown, but the fragment itself does not contain any non-const pointer that should be const-qualified. Therefore there are no code fragments in this snippet that require investigation for Rule 8.13.
